Award.AwardTitle: Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mission of the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) is to make connections between a broad spectrum of mathematicians and scientists, to launch new collaborations, to better inform mathematicians and scientists about interdisciplinary problems, and to broaden the range of applications in which mathematics is used. Funding from this proposal will support IPAM's mission through programs that bring together researchers from many different fields for periods ranging from 1 day to 3 months, as well as a activities aimed at education and at increasing diversity in mathematics and science. Almost every program combines mathematics and a field of science or engineering; most programs include both pure and applied mathematics; IPAM has focused on important emerging topics, such as proteomics, internet search engines, compressed sensing, nanosystems, virtual surgery, and document space. In programs where there is an emphasis on pure mathematics, IPAM works to create ties between different groups of researchers working on related problems.

IPAM's research programs enhance the vitality of mathematics by promoting interactions between different fields of mathematics and between mathematics and science; they promote new research collaborations; they help the career development of graduate students, postdocs and junior faculty; and they launch both junior and senior scientists on new research directions. The net effect is to build new scientific communities that can address the complex scientific challenges of our time. IPAM's education and diversity activities increase the flow of students into the scientific workforce and encourage the full participation of women and underrepresented minorities in mathematics and science. This is of tremendous importance for the vitality of mathematics and science in the broader community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) are to enable the mathematics that is needed for current and future technological and social progress. Mathematics is an essential ingredient in internet search engines, medical imaging such as MRIs and CAT scans, voice recognition systems, DNA sequencing methods, financial markets and many other systems.

To pursue its goals, IPAM sponsors programs and workshops that bring in thousands of visitors annually, who stay at IPAM for periods of between one day and three months. They range from undergraduate students to Nobel Laureates, and come from academia, government and industry. IPAM brings together mathematicians and researchers from other disciplines, including doctors, engineers, physical scientists, social scientists and humanists. Through these interactions, IPAM builds new research communities that tackle scientific challenges of today and the future. IPAM also offers programs that encourage the inclusion of women and underrepresented minorities in mathematics and public lectures aimed at the university and the broader community.

During the 5 years of this grant, IPAM ran more than 150 workshops and programs, involving nearly 11,000 participants.  Of these, 22.4% of program participants were women, and 11.5% were members of underrepresented ethnic groups.  IPAM also presented 19 public lectures.

Some of the outstanding results from these activities include the following:

The 2011 workshop on Mathematics of Traffic Flow explored the use of mathematic for monitoring, predicting and controlling traffic. A highlight was the development of new approaches to reducing freeway congestion and managing crises (e.g., significant accidents) through unified management of the “traffic corridor”, which includes the freeway as well as the adjoining arterial streets.

A 2012 workshop on Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) established collaborations between mathematicians and government scientists (many from the military). SAR is one of the most effective and widely used radar modalities, but it can have problems with tall buildings and moving objects (e.g. cars). The combination of mathematical and engineering approaches seems promising for overcoming these challenges.

In pure math, the 2012 workshop on Nonlocal PDEs, Variational Problems and their Applications brought together PDE researchers with mathematicians working on variational problems in image processing, materials science and other fields. The 2013 program Interactions of Analysis and Geometry combined the fields in its title.  The 2014 program Algebraic Techniques for Computational and Combinatorial Geometry (CCG) involved specialists in algebraic geometry, analysis, combinatorics, number theory, and also foundations of computer science.

Discovery of new materials is essential for development of improved solar cells, batteries, thermal coatings and drugs, and much of this discovery is done by exhaustive search of the many possible materials. Machine Learning (ML) is a new Artificial Intelligence (AI) method, and has been remarkably successful for voice recognition, facial recognition and other tasks. IPAM’s 2011 program on Navigating Chemical Compound Space brought materials and computer scientists together, and initiated the application of ML to materials science with impressive preliminary results. This was continued in a workshop on Machine Learning for Many-Particle Systems in 2015.

Latinas/os in Mathematics Conference (2015) featured research talks, student events, and networking activities. The goal of the conference was to encourage Latina/os to pursue careers in the mathematical sciences, to promote the advancement of Latina/os currently in the discipline, and to showcase research being conducted by Latina/os at the forefront of their fields. Edward James Olmos (of “Stand and Deliver” and “Battlestar Galactica” fame) was the banquet speaker and encouraged the participants to pursue their ambitions.

Women in Shape (WiSh): Modeling Boundaries of Objects in 2- and 3-Dimensions (2013) was designed to strengthen the shape modeling community by bringing together women researchers at various stages in their careers (from graduate student to senior researcher) to foster research collaboration and mentorship. WiSH participants worked together in small groups to solve open questions in shape modeling, and they developed productive new collaborations.

The public lecture "Toward Brain Computer Interfacing” by Klaus-Robert Muller (Free University, Berlin) in 2013 described the use of brain signals for the control of objects (e.g., wheel chairs), spelling, computer gaming, and other applications. This talk showed the wealth, complexity and difficulties in development of effective brain-computer interfaces. It emphasized the role of Machine Learning as a technique for improving the learning process required for both human and computer.

The public lecture “Some People Have All the Luck” was presented in 2014 by three speakers: Skip Garibaldi (IPAM Associate Director), Lawrence Mower (reporter for the Palm Beach Post), and Philip B. Stark (UC Berkeley statistician). They used mathematics and statistics to investigate the records of individuals who had won many lottery prizes, and to determine the likelihood that cheating had occurred.
